awd_titl_txt: Polymer Symposium Support for the 72nd Southeastern Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society (SERMACS 2021)
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award offers partial support for the polymer symposium of the Southeastern Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society (SERMACS), which is scheduled for November 2021 in Birmingham, Alabama.

The following topics will be included in the symposium:   1. New routes for the synthesis of stimuli-sensitive polymers.   2. Assembly of amphiphilic polymers in solutions into nanoscale structures.   3. Structural parameters controlling micelles vs. polymersome assembly in solutions.   4. Kinetics and thermodynamics of polymer complexation in solutions.    5. Interfacial stabilization of self-assembled structures.   6. Templated assemblies: 2D coatings and 3D hollow capsules.   7. Free-standing and free-floating films.   8. Structure-property-function relationships of polymer assemblies.

Additionally, the symposium offers essential opportunities for junior faculty members, students, and postdoctoral researchers, including a significant number of women, to network with senior researchers.    The meeting talks will be publicized through the dedicated SERMAC website.  Students will be encouraged to present at a poster session, and there will be activities and workshops for faculty candidates and for students to explore career opportunities.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This Award supported the one-day symposium " Polymer Assemblies: from Fundamental to Applications?" held November 10th-13th, 2021, at the 72nd Southeastern Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society (SERMACS 2021) in Birmingham, AL, organized by Dr. Eugenia Kharlampieva (the University of Alabama at Birmingham). The symposium was open to all interested materials scientists, chemists, and engineers actively working on topics related to polymer science.

Intellectual Merit. The Southeastern Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society (SERMACS) is held each fall.  These regional meetings are primarily targeted but not limited to the participation of the Southeastern United States.  The polymer symposium brought together new ideas and directions to discuss the fundamentals of polymer science, including its theoretical and experimental aspects. It also addressed emerging applications of polymer materials. Major distinguishing features of the symposium included an emphasis on increased participation of young faculty, postdoctoral associates, and graduate students, in-depth discussions of fundamentals of polymer self-assembly assembly, and a broad representation of applications of self-assembled materials and transformative research. The symposium provided a forum for scientists and engineers involved in the macromolecular synthesis and stimuli-triggered macromolecular self-assembly to tailor biological, chemical, and physical properties of self-assembled materials to share the most recent advances made in this rapidly expanding field.

Broader Impact. The symposium brought together leading scientists working in the interdisciplinary area of polymer synthesis, assembly in solutions, and interfacial stabilization of self-assembled structures. This symposium hosted one full day of sixteen oral presentations from four newly appointed assistant professors, seven established researchers, two postdoctoral scholars, and three graduate students who showcased their research and emphasized new trends and future directions at the interface of colloidal science and acoustic interactions. A significant feature of the event was the participation of women, nearly 50% of the presenters, including female researchers at the student, postdoctoral, and faculty levels. The participation of junior researchers was strongly encouraged and turned out to be successful, as postdoctoral fellows and graduate students had the opportunity to interact with senior researchers and present the research results. The audience for this symposium included graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, junior and senior faculty, and scientists from the industry. Overall, this symposium offered vital opportunities for junior faculty members, students, and postdoctoral fellows, including a significant number of female researchers, to interact and exchange their knowledge and experience.


Last Modified: 11/23/2022
Modified by: Richard A Dluhy
